page.title: 05SOME RARE BIRDS OF OVERY
page.content: The Avocet is quite a rare bird in many parts of Britain and even here in Norfolk. At Overy Staithe we are lucky enough to have one or two visiting occasionally. The Avocet is a wader, its colour is black and white and it has a long curved beak which it uses to probe for food in the mud and sand. The Heron is quite popular in Norfolk but is still a rarity in most of Britain. Herons are also waders and their food is fish. Sometimes they have been known to steal goldfish from people's ponds. The species of gull and Overy are the Great Black-backed Gull, the Herring Gull, Black-headed Gull and Lesser Black-Backed Gull. They are all scavengers. The Terns that nest on Scolt Head Island near Overy are: Arctic Tern, Common Tern and Sandwich Tern.
